case_name: Uttar Pradesh Co-operative Federation Limited v. Sunder Brothers

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 426 of 1964 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 426 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated Februa

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated February 22, 1962 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Revision No. 311-D of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 22, 1962 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Revision No. 311-D of 1958.

facts.text: Punjab High Court upheld and confirmed the judgment of the Appellate Court and set aside the judgment of the trial court staying proceedings in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: P. Sinha and Inder Sen Sawhney, for the appellant, K. Jain and Bishambar Lal, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J. This appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the Punjab High Court dated February 22, 1962 in Civil Revision No. 331-D of 1958 whereby the High Court upheld and confirmed the judgment of the Appellate Court and set aside the judgment of the trial court staying proceedings in the suit.

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Co-operative Federation Limited was registered under the Cooperative Societies Act No. II of 1912 at Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: The Uttar Pradesh Co-operative Federation Limited  herein- after referred to as the Society  was registered under the Cooperative Societies Act No. II of 1912 at Lucknow and was carrying on the business of plying public carriers on Kanpur-Delhi route.

facts.text: Society was carrying on the business of plying public carriers on Kanpur-Delhi route.

anchor.surface_text: and was carrying on the business of plying public carriers on Kanpur-Delhi route. The Society had been granted, for this purpose, permits by the Uttar Pradesh Government and Delhi Administration for seven vehicles.

facts.text: Society had been granted permits by the Uttar Pradesh Government and Delhi Administration for seven vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: The Society had been granted, for this purpose, permits by the Uttar Pradesh Government and Delhi Administration for seven vehicles. In March, 1954, the Society entered into an agreement with the plaintiffs-M s Sunder Brothers-through Bimal Kumar Jain and Dhan Kumar Jain by which they were appointed as Managing Agents for carrying on the business as public carriers.

facts.text: In March 1954, Society entered into an agreement with plaintiffs Ms Sunder Brothers through Bimal Kumar Jain and Dhan Kumar Jain appointing them as Managing Agents.

anchor.surface_text: In March, 1954, the Society entered into an agreement with the plaintiffs-M s Sunder Brothers-through Bimal Kumar Jain and Dhan Kumar Jain by which they were appointed as Managing Agents for carrying on the business as public carriers. The terms of the Managing Agency agreement were embodied in a letter dated March 2, 1954 written by the Secretary of the Society.

facts.text: Terms of Managing Agency agreement embodied in letter dated March 2, 1954 written by Secretary of the Society.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the Managing Agency agreement were embodied in a letter dated March 2, 1954 written by the Secretary of the Society. Clause 28 of the agreement reads as follows- That in the event of there being any dispute regarding the terms and conditions of this agreement and your appointment hereunder as Managing Agents of the aforesaid business or any matter arising from and relating thereto or the subject matter thereof, such dispute shall be decided by arbitration as provided under Co-operative Societies Act II of 1912 and you undertake and agree to be bound by the provisions for arbitration in the said Act.

facts.text: Clause 28 of the agreement provides that disputes shall be decided by arbitration under Cooperative Societies Act II of 1912.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 28 of the agreement reads as follows- That in the event of there being any dispute regarding the terms and conditions of this agreement and your appointment hereunder as Managing Agents of the aforesaid business or any matter arising from and relating thereto or the subject matter thereof, such dispute shall be decided by arbitration as provided under Co-operative Societies Act II of 1912 and you undertake and agree to be bound by the provisions for arbitration in the said Act. The agreement was to last for a period of three years but on July 5, 1954 the Society terminated the agreement by its letter dated July 5, 1954,

facts.text: Agreement was to last for three years but terminated by Society on July 5, 1954 by letter.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement was to last for a period of three years but on July 5, 1954 the Society terminated the agreement by its letter dated July 5, 1954, The plaintiffs therefore brought a suit on August 18, 1954 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Delhi praying for a declaration that the termination of the Managing Agency agreement by the Society was illegal and the plaintiffs were entitled to continue the business of Managing Agents in accordance with the terms and conditions of the agreement.

facts.text: Plaintiffs brought suit on August 18, 1954 in Court of Subordinate Judge First Class Delhi for declaration that termination was illegal and for mandatory injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs therefore brought a suit on August 18, 1954 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Delhi praying for a declaration that the termination of the Managing Agency agreement by the Society was illegal and the plaintiffs were entitled to continue the business of Managing Agents in accordance with the terms and conditions of the agreement. The plaintiffs prayed for a mandatory injunction restraining the defendant-Society from terminating the agreement.

facts.text: Society made application under S.34 Indian Arbitration Act 1940 before Subordinate Judge Delhi for staying the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Society made an application under S. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940 before the Subordinate Judge, Delhi, for an order for staying the suit. It was claimed by the Society that the suit was not maintainable, because under S. 51 of the Co-operative Societies Act the dispute was to be adjudicated upon by the Registrar of Co-operative Societies.

facts.text: Society claimed suit not maintainable under S.51 Cooperative Societies Act to be adjudicated by Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed by the Society that the suit was not maintainable, because under S. 51 of the Co-operative Societies Act the dispute was to be adjudicated upon by the Registrar of Co-operative Societies. In the alternative it was alleged that by agreement between the parties the dispute was to be referred to arbitration in accordance with the Co- operative Societies Act and consequently proceedings should be stayed.

facts.text: Trial court stayed the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court stayed the proceedings but on the appeal of the plaintiffs the order of the trial court was set aside and the application of the Society under S. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act was dismissed.

facts.text: On appeal by plaintiffs, Appellate Court set aside trial court's stay order and dismissed Society's S.34 application.

anchor.surface_text: but on the appeal of the plaintiffs the order of the trial court was set aside and the application of the Society under S. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act was dismissed. The Society moved the Punjab High Court in revision but the revision application was dismissed and the order of the lower appellate court was confirmed.

facts.text: Society moved Punjab High Court in revision, but application dismissed confirming lower appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: The Society moved the Punjab High Court in revision but the revision application was dismissed and the order of the lower appellate court was confirmed.

facts.text: Suit was filed in 1954 and after 12 years nothing has been done in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed in-1954 and, though 12 years have elapsed, nothing has been, done in the suit and it will not be in the interest of speedy disposal of the suit between the parties-if the proceedings in the suit are further stayed and the parties are referred to arbitration.

facts.text: Respondent alleged that Registrar of Co-operative Societies is ex-officio President of the Society.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged by the respondent that the Registrar of Co-operative Societies is ex-officio President of the Society and it was with his approval that the agreement in dispute was terminated.

facts.text: Respondent alleged that termination of agreement was with approval of Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: and it was with his approval that the agreement in dispute was terminated. It was also pointed out that the Registrar was the chief controlling and supervising officer of the Society under its bye-laws.

facts.text: Registrar was the chief controlling and supervising officer of the Society under its bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out that the Registrar was the chief controlling and supervising officer of the Society under its bye-laws. It was submitted for the respondent that the Registrar may not, therefore, act fairly in the matter and it is improper that he should be an arbitrator in the dispute between the parties.

facts.text: High Court observed it would be difficult for arbitrator to investigate consistency of Co-operative Societies Rules with Indian Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: It has been observed by the High Court that it would be a difficult task for the arbitrator to investigate as to which of the rules made under the Co-operative Societies Act are consistent with and which of those rules are not consistent with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act and therefore it was, a fit case in which discretion of the court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act should be exercised in not staying the proceedings of the suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court properly exercised discretion in not granting stay.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the High Court properly exercised its discretion under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act in not granting a stay of the proceedings in the suit.

issues.text: Whether the arbitration under clause 28 of the agreement was a statutory arbitration under section 46 of the Indian Arbitration Act or an arbitration agreement under section 47

anchor.surface_text: There was some controversy in the lower courts as to whether the arbitration under cl. 28 of the agreement was a statutory arbitration and whether s. 46 of the Indian Arbitration Act was applicable to the case. It was argued by Mr. Sinha on behalf of the appellant-Society that no statutory arbitration is created by cl. 28 of the agreement but the parties had merely agreed to act in accordance with the provisions of the Co-operative Societies Act Act II of 1912 and the Rules made thereunder.

issues.text: Whether the lower court rightly exercised its jurisdiction under section 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act in not granting the stay of the proceedings of the suit

anchor.surface_text: The only question in debate was whether the lower court rightly exercised their jurisdiction under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act in not granting the stay of the proceedings of the suit. If the arbitration agreement is not to be treated as a statutory arbitration under s. 46 of the Arbitration Act but an arbitration agreement under s. 47 of the Act, then the procedure to be followed for the arbitration under that agreement will be that provided under the Co-operative Societies Act and the Rules framed thereunder.

issues.text: Whether the discretion under section 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act should not be exercised to stay the suit due to the difficult task for the arbitrator to determine consistency of Co-operative Societies Rules with the Arbitration Act

anchor.surface_text: It has been observed by the High Court that it would be a difficult task for the arbitrator to investigate as to which of the rules made under the Co-operative Societies Act are consistent with and which of those rules are not consistent with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act and therefore it was, a fit case in which discretion of the court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act should be exercised in not staying the proceedings of the suit.

issues.text: Whether there is good ground for apprehending that the Registrar of Co-operative Societies will not act fairly or it is improper for him to be the arbitrator

anchor.surface_text: the Registrar may not, therefore, act fairly in the matter and it is improper that he should be an arbitrator in the dispute between the parties. In our opinion, there is much validity in this argument. The legal position is that an order of stay of suit under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act will not be granted if it can be shown that there is good ground for apprehending that the arbitrator will not act fairly in the matter or that it is for some reason improper that he should arbitrate in the dispute between the parties.

issues.text: Whether further stay of the suit is in the interest of speedy disposal given the long delay since filing

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the reasoning of the High Court has much substance. There is also another reason why there should not be a stay of the proceedings under S. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act. The suit was filed in-1954 and, though 12 years have elapsed, nothing has been, done in the suit and it will not be in the interest of speedy disposal of the suit between the parties-if the proceedings in the suit are further stayed and the parties are referred to arbitration.

issues.text: Whether the appellate court should interfere with the exercise of discretion under section 34 by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that where the discretion vested in the Court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act has been exercised by the lower court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of that discretion. In dealing with the matter raised before it at the appellate stage the appellate court would normally not be justified in interfering with the exercise of the discretion under appeal solely on the ground that if it had considered the matter at the trial stage it may have come to a contrary conclusion.

arguments.claim: High Court properly exercised discretion under S.34 in not granting stay

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the High Court properly exercised its discretion under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act in number granting a stay of the proceedings in the suit.

holdings.text: The arbitration under clause 28 of the agreement is not a statutory arbitration under section 46 of the Indian Arbitration Act but an arbitration agreement under section 47.

anchor.surface_text: There was some controversy in the lower courts as to whether the arbitration under cl. 28 of the agreement was a statutory arbitration and whether s. 46 of the Indian Arbitration Act was applicable to the case. It was argued by Mr. Sinha on behalf of the appellant-Society that no statutory arbitration is created by cl. 28 of the agreement but the parties had merely agreed to act in accordance with the provisions of the Co-operative Societies Act Act II of 1912 and the Rules made thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties incorporated Co-operative Societies Act arbitration provisions by reference in agreement; argument not controverted by respondent.

holdings.text: The reasoning of the High Court that it would be difficult for the arbitrator to determine consistency of Co-operative Societies Rules with Arbitration Act has much substance warranting no stay under section 34.

anchor.surface_text: It has been observed by the High Court that it would be a difficult task for the arbitrator to investigate as to which of the rules made under the Co-operative Societies Act are consistent with and which of those rules are not consistent with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act and therefore it was, a fit case in which discretion of the court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act should be exercised in not staying the proceedings of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrator lacks authority to decide which rules apply, making arbitration impractical.

holdings.text: Further stay not in interest of speedy disposal given 12 years delay since suit filed in 1954 with no progress.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the reasoning of the High Court has much substance. There is also another reason why there should not be a stay of the proceedings under S. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act. The suit was filed in-1954 and, though 12 years have elapsed, nothing has been, done in the suit and it will not be in the interest of speedy disposal of the suit between the parties-if the proceedings in the suit are further stayed and the parties are referred to arbitration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prolonged inaction favors continuing suit over new arbitration.

holdings.text: Stay under section 34 not granted if good ground to apprehend arbitrator will not act fairly or improper for him to arbitrate.

anchor.surface_text: the Registrar may not, therefore, act fairly in the matter and it is improper that he should be an arbitrator in the dispute between the parties. In our opinion, there is much validity in this argument. The legal position is that an order of stay of suit under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act will not be granted if it can be shown that there is good ground for apprehending that the arbitrator will not act fairly in the matter or that it is for some reason improper that he should arbitrate in the dispute between the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registrar ex-officio President who approved termination and controls society; risk of bias.

holdings.text: Normal duty to enforce arbitration agreement unless good ground for apprehension of unfairness or impropriety by arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: It is, of course, the normal duty of the Court to hold the parties to the contract and to make them present their disputes to the forum of their choice but an order to stay the legal proceedings in a Court of law will not be granted if-it is shown that there is good ground for apprehending that the arbitrator will not act fairly in the matter or that it is for some reason improper that he should arbitrate in the dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances sanctity of contract with fairness in arbitration.

holdings.text: Strict principle of sanctity of contract subject to court discretion under section 34; implied condition that arbitration enforceable only if court deems fit.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the strict principle of sanctity of contract is subject to the discretion of the Court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act, for there must be read in every such agreement an implied term or condition that it would be enforceable only if the Court, having due regard to the other surrounding circumstances, thinks fit in its discretion to enforce it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Every arbitration agreement implies court discretion condition per legislation.

holdings.text: Party released from arbitration if arbitrator likely biased, suspected unfair, or unreasonable conduct.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that a party may be released from the bargain if he can show that the selected arbitrator is likely to show bias or by sufficient reason to suspect that he will act unfairly or that he has been guilty of continued unreasonable conduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principles of natural justice apply to arbitrators.

holdings.text: High Court properly exercised discretion under section 34 in not granting stay.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the High Court properly exercised its discretion under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act in not granting a stay of the proceedings in the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple valid reasons including bias apprehension, procedural difficulty, and delay justify refusal of stay.

holdings.text: Appellate court slow to interfere with lower court's exercise of discretion under section 34 unless unreasonable, capricious, or ignoring facts.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that where the discretion vested in the Court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act has been exercised by the lower court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of that discretion. In dealing with the matter raised before it at the appellate stage the appellate court would normally not be justified in interfering with the exercise of the discretion under appeal solely on the ground that if it had considered the matter at the trial stage it may have come to a contrary conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows established principles from precedents like Charles Osenton; High Court acted judicially.

holdings.text: Appellant has made out no case for interference with High Court's order refusing stay under section 34.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court discretion properly exercised; no perversity warranting reversal.

anchor.surface_text: There was some controversy in the lower courts as to whether the arbitration under cl. 28 of the agreement was a statutory arbitration and whether s. 46 of the Indian Arbitration Act was applicable to the case. It was argued by Mr. Sinha on behalf of the appellant-Society that no statutory arbitration is created by cl. 28 of the agreement but the parties had merely agreed to act in accordance with the provisions of the Co-operative Societies Act Act II of 1912 and the Rules made thereunder.
For these reasons we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for our interference with the order of the High Court refusing stay of the proceedings in

anchor.surface_text: It has been observed by the High Court that it would be a difficult task for the arbitrator to investigate as to which of the rules made under the Co-operative Societies Act are consistent with and which of those rules are not consistent with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act and therefore it was, a fit case in which discretion of the court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act should be exercised in not staying the proceedings of the suit.
For these reasons we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for our interference with the order of the High Court refusing stay of the proceedings in

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the reasoning of the High Court has much substance. There is also another reason why there should not be a stay of the proceedings under S. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act. The suit was filed in-1954 and, though 12 years have elapsed, nothing has been, done in the suit and it will not be in the interest of speedy disposal of the suit between the parties-if the proceedings in the suit are further stayed and the parties are referred to arbitration.
For these reasons we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for our interference with the order of the High Court refusing stay of the proceedings in

anchor.surface_text: the Registrar may not, therefore, act fairly in the matter and it is improper that he should be an arbitrator in the dispute between the parties. In our opinion, there is much validity in this argument. The legal position is that an order of stay of suit under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act will not be granted if it can be shown that there is good ground for apprehending that the arbitrator will not act fairly in the matter or that it is for some reason improper that he should arbitrate in the dispute between the parties.
For these reasons we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for our interference with the order of the High Court refusing stay of the proceedings in

edges.explanation: The holding directly addresses the issue by stating the appellate court is slow to interfere with discretion under section 34 unless unreasonable, capricious, or ignoring facts, embodying Wednesbury unreasonableness.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that where the discretion vested in the Court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act has been exercised by the lower court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of that discretion. In dealing with the matter raised before it at the appellate stage the appellate court would normally not be justified in interfering with the exercise of the discretion under appeal solely on the ground that if it had considered the matter at the trial stage it may have come to a contrary conclusion.
For these reasons we hold that the appellant has made out numbercase for our interference with the order of the High Court refusing stay of the proceedings in
